document: Digital health is a rapidly evolving discipline that aims to enhance healthcare delivery by integrating digital care programs and technologies with healthcare, living, and society. It utilizes information and communication technologies to address health problems and challenges faced by individuals receiving medical treatment and social prescribing in a more personalized and precise manner. The field of digital health encompasses various stakeholders, including clinicians, researchers, scientists, and experts from healthcare, engineering, social sciences, public health, health economics, and data management. It involves a wide range of hardware and software solutions and services, such as telemedicine, wearable devices, augmented reality, and virtual reality. The increasing worldwide adoption of electronic medical records, particularly in countries with universal healthcare, has played a significant role in driving the growth of digital health.
noref_document: Digital health is a rapidly growing field that leverages technology to improve healthcare delivery and overall well-being. It encompasses a wide range of digital tools and platforms, such as mobile apps, wearable devices, electronic health records, and telemedicine services. These innovative solutions are transforming the way we engage with our health, enabling us to remotely monitor vital signs, access medical information, track fitness goals, and even receive virtual consultations from healthcare professionals. Digital health has the potential to enhance patient outcomes, increase access to healthcare services, streamline administrative processes, and empower individuals to take greater control of their own health.
summary:
Digital health is a discipline that includes digital care programs, technologies with health, healthcare, living, and society to enhance the efficiency of healthcare delivery and to make medicine more personalized and precise. It uses information and communication technologies to facilitate understanding of health problems and challenges faced by people receiving medical treatment and social prescribing in more personalised and precise ways. The definitions of digital health and its remits overlap in many ways with those of health and medical informatics.
Worldwide adoption of electronic medical records has been on the rise since 1990 and is closely correlated with the existence of universal health care. Digital health is a multi-disciplinary domain involving many stakeholders, including clinicians, researchers and scientists with a wide range of expertise in healthcare, engineering, social sciences, public health, health economics and data management.Digital health technologies include both hardware and software solutions and services, including telemedicine, wearable devices, augmented reality, and virtual reality.

document: Space debris, also known as space junk or space pollution, refers to nonfunctional human-made objects in Earth's orbit that serve no useful purpose. This includes derelict spacecraft, abandoned launch vehicle stages, and fragments from their disintegration. Additionally, space debris can consist of erosion, collisions, paint flecks, solidified liquids expelled from spacecraft, and unburned particles from solid rocket motors. These fragments pose a significant risk to functioning spacecraft. The space industry is actively involved in measuring, mitigating, and potentially removing space debris. As of November 2022, the US Space Surveillance Network has identified 25,857 artificial objects in orbit, including 5,465 operational satellites.
noref_document: Space debris refers to the collection of defunct, man-made objects floating in space. This debris consists of spent rocket stages, old satellites, fragments from explosions, and other remnants resulting from human activities in space. With the growing number of satellites being launched and the increase in space exploration, space debris has become a critical concern. These objects pose a significant threat to active satellites and the International Space Station, as they travel at high speeds and can cause catastrophic collisions. Efforts are being made to mitigate space debris, including tracking and monitoring systems, guidelines for responsible space operations, and even ideas for active debris removal.
summary:
Space debris (also known as space junk, space pollution, space waste, space trash, space garbage, or cosmic debris) are defunct human-made objects in space – principally in Earth orbit – which no longer serve a useful function. These include derelict spacecraft – nonfunctional spacecraft and abandoned launch vehicle stages – mission-related debris, and particularly numerous in Earth orbit, fragmentation debris from the breakup of derelict rocket bodies and spacecraft. In addition to derelict human-made objects left in orbit, other examples of space debris include fragments from their disintegration, erosion and collisions or even paint flecks, solidified liquids expelled from spacecraft, and unburned particles from solid rocket motors. Space debris represents a risk to spacecraft.Space debris is typically a negative externality – it creates an external cost on others from the initial action to launch or use a spacecraft in near-Earth orbit – a cost that is typically not taken into account nor fully accounted for in the cost by the launcher or payload owner.Several spacecraft, both crewed and uncrewed, have been damaged or destroyed by space debris.
The measurement, mitigation, and potential removal of debris are conducted by some participants in the space industry.As of November 2022, the US Space Surveillance Network reported 25,857 artificial objects in orbit above the Earth, including 5,465 operational satellites.

document: Nuclear fusion, the powerful reaction that occurs when two or more atomic nuclei combine, is an extraordinary process that holds immense potential. It involves the fusion of deuterium and tritium, variants of hydrogen, resulting in the formation of new atomic nuclei and subatomic particles. The remarkable aspect of this reaction lies in the difference in mass between the reactants and products, which leads to either the release or absorption of energy. This discrepancy in mass arises from variations in nuclear binding energy before and after the fusion reaction. Not only does nuclear fusion power active or main-sequence stars and other high-magnitude stars, but it also has the ability to generate large amounts of energy on Earth if harnessed effectively. In fact, fusion processes that produce atomic nuclei lighter than iron-56 or nickel-62 typically release energy, representing a promising avenue for sustainable and clean energy production.
noref_document: Nuclear fusion is a process that involves the creation of energy by combining atomic nuclei together. This concept holds great promise as a potential source of clean, abundant, and sustainable energy. Unlike nuclear fission, which is currently used in nuclear power plants, fusion does not produce long-lived radioactive waste or pose the risks associated with nuclear accidents. Scientists and researchers worldwide are diligently working to develop the technology required to harness fusion power. If successful, fusion could revolutionize the energy industry and address the growing concerns surrounding climate change and limited fossil fuel resources.
summary:
Nuclear fusion is a reaction in which two or more atomic nuclei, usually deuterium and tritium (hydrogen variants), are combined to form one or more different atomic nuclei and subatomic particles (neutrons or protons). The difference in mass between the reactants and products is manifested as either the release or absorption of energy. This difference in mass arises due to the difference in nuclear binding energy between the atomic nuclei before and after the reaction. Nuclear fusion is the process that powers active or main-sequence stars and other high-magnitude stars, where large amounts of energy are released.
A nuclear fusion process that produces atomic nuclei lighter than iron-56 or nickel-62 will generally release energy.

A nuclear fusion process that produces atomic nuclei lighter than iron-56 or nickel-62 will generally release energy.

document: Digital currency refers to any form of currency or money-like asset primarily managed, stored, or exchanged on digital computer systems, typically over the internet. It encompasses various types such as cryptocurrency, virtual currency, and central bank digital currency. Unlike traditional fiat currency, digital currencies lack a physical form like banknotes or coins. However, they do possess a unique "unclassical" physicality stemming from the interactions between computers and humans, as well as the processing power of servers that store and track digital money. This characteristic enables nearly instant transactions and significantly reduces the costs associated with distributing physical cash. For instance, in the UK economy, electronic money in the form of bank deposits constitutes a substantial 79%, while notes and coins account for only 3% of the total money supply.
noref_document: Digital currency, also known as cryptocurrency, is a form of digital or virtual currency that utilizes cryptography for secure financial transactions, control the creation of additional units, and verify the transfer of assets. One of the most well-known digital currencies is Bitcoin, which was introduced in 2009 and has gained significant popularity since then. The rise of digital currencies has brought attention to the potential benefits of decentralized financial systems, as they eliminate the need for intermediaries such as banks and allow for more transparent peer-to-peer transactions. While digital currencies offer convenience and potential for quick international transfers, concerns about security, regulation, and environmental impact still remain.
summary: Digital currency (digital money, electronic money or electronic currency) is any currency, money, or money-like asset that is primarily managed, stored or exchanged on digital computer systems, especially over the internet. Types of digital currencies include cryptocurrency, virtual currency and central bank digital currency. Digital currency may be recorded on a distributed database on the internet, a centralized electronic computer database owned by a company or bank, within digital files or even on a stored-value card.Digital currencies exhibit properties similar to traditional currencies, but generally do not have a classical physical form of fiat currency historically that can be held in the hand, like currencies with printed banknotes or minted coins. However, they do have a physical form in an unclassical sense coming from the computer to computer and computer to human interactions and the information and processing power of the servers that store and keep track of money. This unclassical physical form allows nearly instantaneous transactions over the internet and vastly lowers the cost associated with distributing notes and coins: for example, of the types of money in the UK economy, 3% are notes and coins, and 79% as electronic money (in the form of bank deposits).

document: The metaverse, a concept that originated from science fiction, envisions a single, all-encompassing virtual world enabled by virtual reality and augmented reality technology. In colloquial usage, the metaverse refers to a network of three-dimensional virtual worlds that emphasize social and economic connections. With increasing demands for immersive experiences, metaverse development is often linked to advancements in virtual reality. The recent fascination with the metaverse has been influenced by the concept of Web3, which envisions a decentralized version of the internet. However, it is important to note that the terms "Web3" and "metaverse" are sometimes used as buzzwords to overstate the progress of related technologies and projects for PR purposes.
noref_document: The Metaverse is a term used to describe a virtual reality space where people can interact with a computer-generated world and each other. It encompasses a vast network of augmented reality, virtual reality, and 3D immersive environments that exist within the digital realm. In the Metaverse, users can explore various simulated environments, engage in social activities, create and trade virtual goods, and even conduct business transactions. It has gained considerable attention in recent years, fueled by advancements in technology and the growing popularity of virtual reality. The concept of the Metaverse holds enormous potential for sectors like entertainment, gaming, education, and even remote work, as it offers a new level of immersive and experiential ways to engage with digital content and connect with others.
summary: In science fiction, the "metaverse" is a hypothetical iteration of the Internet as a single, universal, and immersive virtual world that is facilitated by the use of virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) headsets. In colloquial usage, a "metaverse" is a network of 3D virtual worlds focused on social and economic connection.The term "metaverse" originated in the 1992 science fiction novel Snow Crash as a portmanteau of "meta" and "universe". Metaverse development is often linked to advancing virtual reality technology due to the increasing demands for immersion. Recent interest in metaverse development is influenced by Web3, a concept for a decentralized iteration of the internet. Web3 and metaverse have been used as buzzwords to exaggerate the development progress of various related technologies and projects for public relations purposes.

document: Holography, a fascinating technique that allows the recording and reconstruction of wavefronts, is best known for its ability to generate real three-dimensional images. However, its applications span far beyond this. With holography, it is possible to create holograms for any type of wave, opening up a world of possibilities. By superimposing a reference beam onto the wavefront of interest, an interference pattern is formed and recorded on a physical medium. When the reference beam illuminates the interference pattern, it diffracts and recreates the original wavefront, resulting in the impressive holographic effect. This versatile method has found applications in various industries, from microscopy and microscopy to non-destructive testing and security measures. Its ability to capture and recreate intricate details has made it a valuable tool in fields like medicine, art, and telecommunications. Holography truly showcases the amazing potential of wave manipulation and visualization.
noref_document: Holography, the technique that produces three-dimensional images, has significantly impacted various industries and scientific fields. By utilizing the principle of light diffraction, holography creates a realistic representation of an object or scene, providing depth and visual coherence. This innovative technology finds applications in diverse fields such as entertainment, medical imaging, security, and engineering. In the entertainment industry, holograms have gained popularity for their ability to resurrect deceased artists on stage, captivating audiences with awe-inspiring performances. Moreover, holographic medical imaging allows doctors to obtain a detailed view of internal organs and structures, aiding in accurate diagnoses and surgical planning. Holography also plays a crucial role in the realm of security, with holograms frequently used in banknotes, IDs, and product packaging to prevent counterfeiting. Additionally, holography finds practical application in engineering, enabling the creation of precise and intricate prototypes for various industries. The continuous advancements in holographic technology promise further breakthroughs and opportunities in the years to come.
summary:
Holography is a technique that enables a wavefront to be recorded and later re-constructed. Holography is best known as a method of generating real three-dimensional images, but it also has a wide range of other applications. In principle, it is possible to make a hologram for any type of wave.
A hologram is made by superimposing a second wavefront (normally called the reference beam) on the wavefront of interest, thereby generating an interference pattern which is recorded on a physical medium.   When only the second wavefront illuminates the interference pattern, it is diffracted to recreate the original wavefront.

document: Alternative energy refers to the utilization of renewable resources that naturally replenish on a human timescale. These resources encompass sunlight, wind, the movement of water, and geothermal heat. While most renewable energy sources are sustainable, there are exceptions to this rule. For instance, certain biomass sources are deemed unsustainable due to the current rates of exploitation. The applications of renewable energy extend to electricity generation, as well as heating and cooling systems.

It encompasses a wide range of renewable resources, including solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass. These sources offer several advantages, including reduced greenhouse gas emissions, lower dependence on foreign oil, and the potential for long-term cost savings. As a result, countries and companies around the world are striving to harness the power of alternative energy and develop innovative solutions to meet their energy needs in a sustainable and environmentally friendly way.

document: The dark web, also known as the hidden online world, is a portion of the internet that operates on darknets, requiring specific software, configurations, or authorization to access. It allows private computer networks to communicate and conduct business anonymously, ensuring the protection of identifying information, such as a user's location. While the dark web is often mistakenly referred to as the deep web, it actually represents only a small fraction of it. Darknets within the dark web include various types of networks, ranging from small, friend-to-friend peer-to-peer networks to larger, extensively used networks like Tor, Freenet, I2P, and Riffle, which are operated by both public organizations and individuals. Dark web users commonly refer to the regular web as Clearnet due to its unencrypted nature. The Tor dark web, also known by the domain suffix .onion, employs onion routing to ensure traffic anonymization.
noref_document: The Dark Web is a part of the internet that is not indexed by search engines and is intentionally hidden, accessible only through specific software such as Tor. It is notorious for facilitating illegal activities such as drug trafficking, hacking, and the trading of stolen data. However, the Dark Web also serves as a platform for individuals seeking anonymity and privacy, including activists, whistleblowers, and journalists operating in repressive regimes. While it offers a certain level of secrecy, the Dark Web harbors many dark corners and potential dangers for those who venture into its depths.
summary: The dark web is the World Wide Web content that exists on darknets: overlay networks that use the Internet but require specific software, configurations, or authorization to access. Through the dark web, private computer networks can communicate and conduct business anonymously without divulging identifying information, such as a user's location.  The dark web forms a small part of the deep web, the part of the web not indexed by web search engines, although sometimes the term deep web is mistakenly used to refer specifically to the dark web.The darknets which constitute the dark web include small, friend-to-friend peer-to-peer networks, as well as large, popular networks such as Tor, Freenet, I2P, and Riffle operated by public organizations and individuals. Users of the dark web refer to the regular web as Clearnet due to its unencrypted nature. The Tor dark web or onionland uses the traffic anonymization technique of onion routing under the network's top-level domain suffix .onion.

document: Gene therapy, a groundbreaking medical technology, aims to produce therapeutic effects by manipulating gene expression or altering the biological properties of living cells. Since the first attempt at modifying human DNA in 1980, progress has been made in this field. The first successful nuclear gene transfer in humans was performed in May 1989, with the National Institutes of Health's approval. French Anderson achieved a major milestone in September 1990 by conducting the first therapeutic use of gene transfer and directly inserting human DNA into the nuclear genome. Since then, over 2,900 clinical trials have taken place, with more than half of them in phase I. In 2003, Gendicine became the first gene therapy to obtain regulatory approval. This was followed by the approval of several other gene therapy drugs like Glybera, Strimvelis, Kymriah, Luxturna, Onpattro, Zolgensma, Abecma, Adstiladrin, Roctavian, and Hemgenix. Adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) and lentiviruses are commonly utilized for gene insertions, in vivo and ex vivo, respectively.
noref_document: Gene therapy is a revolutionary medical technique that holds great promise for treating a wide range of diseases and disorders. It involves introducing genetic material into a patient's cells to correct or replace a faulty gene, with the potential to provide long-term solutions instead of just managing symptoms. This approach has the potential to significantly impact the field of medicine by offering targeted and personalized therapies. With ongoing research and advancements, gene therapy could potentially transform the way we treat genetic disorders, cancer, and even certain viral infections in the future.
summary: Gene therapy is a medical technology which aims to produce a therapeutic effect through the manipulation of gene expression or through altering the biological properties of living cells.The first attempt at modifying human DNA was performed in 1980, by Martin Cline, but the first successful nuclear gene transfer in humans, approved by the National Institutes of Health, was performed in May 1989. The first therapeutic use of gene transfer as well as the first direct insertion of human DNA into the nuclear genome was performed by French Anderson in a trial starting in September 1990. Between 1989 and December 2018, over 2,900 clinical trials were conducted, with more than half of them in phase I. In 2003, Gendicine became the first gene therapy to receive regulatory approval. Since that time, further gene therapy drugs were approved, such as Glybera (2012), Strimvelis (2016), Kymriah (2017), Luxturna (2017), Onpattro (2018), Zolgensma (2019), Abecma (2021), Adstiladrin, Roctavian and Hemgenix (all 2022). Most of these approaches utilize adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) and lentiviruses for performing gene insertions, in vivo and ex vivo, respectively.

document: A digital twin, such as the one described in the Wikipedia article, is a virtual replica of a real-world physical product, system, or process. It is created to serve as a practical equivalent to its physical counterpart, enabling activities like simulation, integration, testing, monitoring, and maintenance. Designed as the foundation of Product Lifecycle Management, the digital twin spans the entire life cycle of the represented entity. Importantly, it can exist even prior to the physical entity itself. By utilizing a digital twin during the creation stage, it becomes possible to model and simulate the entire lifecycle of the intended entity. With its flexibility and value-based use cases, the digital twin revolutionizes the way we approach product development and management.
noref_document: A digital twin, as defined by the concept's description on Wikipedia, refers to a virtual replica or representation of a physical object, system, or process. It is created by capturing real-time data from the object or system and feeding it into a software model, which then simulates and visualizes its behavior. Digital twins are commonly used in fields such as manufacturing, healthcare, and urban planning to optimize design, explore various scenarios, and monitor performance in a virtual environment. This technology enables organizations to analyze data and gain valuable insights without directly impacting the real-world counterparts, leading to more efficient and effective decision-making processes.
summary: A digital twin is a digital representation of an intended or actual real-world physical product, system, or process (a physical twin) that serves as the effectively indistinguishable digital counterpart of it for practical purposes, such as simulation, integration, testing, monitoring, and maintenance. The digital twin has been intended from its initial introduction to be the underlying premise for Product Lifecycle Management and exists throughout the entire lifecycle (create, build, operate/support, and dispose) of the physical entity it represents. Since information is granular, the digital twin representation is determined by the value-based use cases it is created to implement. The digital twin can and does often exist before there is a physical entity. The use of a digital twin in the creation phase allows the intended entity's entire lifecycle to be modeled and simulated.

document: Kamala Devi Harris is an American politician and attorney who currently holds the position of the 49th vice president of the United States. Making history, she is the first female vice president and the highest-ranking female official in U.S. history. Additionally, she is the first African-American and first Asian-American vice president. Prior to her current role, Harris served as the attorney general of California from 2011 to 2017 and as a U.S. senator representing California from 2017 to 2021. Born in Oakland, California, she obtained her education from Howard University and the University of California, Hastings College of the Law. Harris commenced her career in the office of the district attorney of Alameda County and later moved on to hold positions in the San Francisco DA's Office and the City Attorney of San Francisco's office.

document: Space tourism, a thrilling concept that has fascinated humanity for decades, allows individuals to embark on exhilarating human space travel purely for recreational purposes. This extraordinary endeavor encompasses various types, from orbital to suborbital and even lunar space tourism. From 2001 to 2009, a total of seven daring space tourists successfully completed eight awe-inspiring space flights aboard the Russian Soyuz spacecraft, venturing towards the magnificent International Space Station. Facilitated by Space Adventures, in collaboration with Roscosmos and RSC Energia, these unprecedented voyages came with a hefty price tag of approximately US$20-25 million per trip. What's particularly intriguing is that some of these adventurous souls have even entered contracts with third parties, engaging in research activities while soaring amidst the stars.
noref_document: A space hotel, also known as an orbital hotel or a space station hotel, is a concept that aims to provide accommodations for space tourists in outer space. These futuristic facilities would offer a unique experience for travelers, allowing them to stay in zero-gravity and witness breathtaking views of Earth from orbit. The idea of a space hotel has gained increasing attention in recent years, with several companies and organizations actively working towards making it a reality. In fact, plans have been proposed for constructing hotels in low Earth orbit, equipped with sleeping quarters, dining areas, and recreational spaces for individuals to enjoy during their stay in space. With technological advancements and growing interest in space exploration, it is possible that we may see the development of space hotels in the not-too-distant future.
summary:
Space tourism is human space travel for recreational purposes. There are several different types of space tourism, including orbital, suborbital and lunar space tourism.
During the period from 2001 to 2009, seven space tourists made eight space flights aboard a Russian Soyuz spacecraft to the International Space Station, brokered by Space Adventures in conjunction with Roscosmos and RSC Energia. The publicized price was in the range of US$20–25 million per trip. Some space tourists have signed contracts with third parties to conduct certain research activities while in orbit.

document: The ethics of artificial intelligence (AI) is a complex and evolving field that focuses on the moral implications of AI technology. It encompasses two main areas of concern: the ethical behavior of humans involved in the design, development, and utilization of AI systems, and the ethical behavior of the AI machines themselves. Within this broader context, there is a specific discipline known as robot ethics, which specifically addresses the moral considerations related to the design, construction, use, and treatment of robots. It is important to note that while AI can exist solely as software, robots are physical machines that may or may not incorporate AI technology.
noref_document: Ethical AI, also known as ethical artificial intelligence, refers to the concept of developing and deploying AI systems that prioritize and adhere to ethical principles. It aims to ensure that AI technologies are designed and used in a way that is beneficial and safe for both individuals and society as a whole. Ethical AI involves addressing various moral and societal considerations such as fairness, accountability, transparency, and privacy. It encourages the development of AI systems that are unbiased, non-discriminatory, and respectful of human rights. To achieve ethical AI, experts and researchers emphasize the need for robust governance frameworks, ethical guidelines, and responsible practices throughout the AI development life cycle.
summary:
The ethics of artificial intelligence is the branch of the ethics of technology specific to artificially intelligent systems. It is sometimes divided into a concern with the moral behavior of humans as they design, make, use and treat artificially intelligent systems, and a concern with the behavior of machines, in machine ethics. 


== Ethics fields' approaches ==


=== Robot ethics ===

The term "robot ethics" (sometimes "roboethics") refers to the morality of how humans design, construct, use and treat robots. Robot ethics intersect with the ethics of AI. Robots are physical machines whereas AI can be only software. Not all robots function through AI systems and not all AI systems are robots.

document: Roger Federer, the Swiss former professional tennis player, is widely regarded as one of the greatest tennis players of all time. With a record-breaking career, Federer held the world No. 1 ranking in singles for an impressive 310 weeks, including an unparalleled streak of 237 consecutive weeks. His dominance on the court is further highlighted by finishing as the year-end No. 1 player five times. Federer's success can be attributed to his exceptional skills and versatility, which have contributed to his remarkable 103 singles titles on the ATP Tour, the second highest in history. Among his incredible accomplishments are his record-breaking 20 major men's singles titles, including an impressive eight Wimbledon titles and a joint-record five US Open titles. Additionally, Federer has triumphed at the prestigious ATP Tour Finals six times, solidifying his reputation as a tennis legend.

document: Emma González, an American activist and advocate for gun control, gained national recognition in 2018 after surviving the Stoneman Douglas High School shooting. In response to the tragedy, González co-founded the gun-control advocacy group Never Again MSD. Their impassioned speech during a rally calling out politicians for their lack of action in the face of gun violence went viral, introducing the powerful phrase "We call B.S." González's role as a leading advocate continued to grow as they made high-profile media appearances and helped organize the March for Our Lives, a nationwide demonstration against gun violence. Notably, González led a poignant moment of silence at the event, standing on stage for six minutes, symbolizing the duration of the shooting spree. Such powerful activism earned González a place on Time magazine's prestigious 100 Most Influential People of 2018 list.

document: Virtual reality gaming, also known as VR gaming, refers to video games that are played on virtual reality (VR) hardware. These games aim to provide players with an immersive experience by utilizing head-mounted display units or headsets with stereoscopic displays, along with one or more controllers. While early attempts at VR gaming were made in the 1980s, it wasn't until the introduction of consumer-ready VR products such as the Oculus Rift in 2013 that VR games gained momentum. Existing games were adapted for VR hardware, and new games were designed specifically for the medium. However, it was the release of Half-Life: Alyx, a full VR game developed by Valve, that was widely regarded as the breakthrough moment for VR gaming.
noref_document: Virtual reality gaming, as defined on Wikipedia, refers to the use of virtual reality technology to create an immersive and interactive gaming experience. It enables players to enter a virtual world and interact with it using specialized headsets and controllers. Virtual reality gaming has gained significant popularity in recent years, offering players a whole new level of immersion and realism. With the ability to explore vast virtual worlds, engage in intense battles, and interact with virtual objects, it has transformed the way people experience and participate in gaming. This technology has also paved the way for innovative gameplay mechanics and unique gaming experiences that were previously impossible.
summary:
A virtual reality game or VR games is a video game played on virtual reality (VR) hardware. Most VR games are based on player immersion, typically through head-mounted display unit or headset with stereoscopic displays and one or more controllers.
The video game industry made early attempts at VR in the 1980s, most notably with Mattel's Power Glove and Nintendo's Virtual Boy. With the introduction of the first consumer-ready VR product, the Oculus Rift, in 2013, VR games soon followed, including existing games adapted for the VR hardware, and new games designed directly for VR. While VR hardware and games grew modestly for the remainder of the 2010s, Half-Life: Alyx, a full VR game developed by Valve, was considered the killer application for VR games.


== History ==


=== Early VR games (1980s-2000s) ===
Research into virtual reality (VR) hardware and software started as early as 1968 by Ivan Sutherland and his student Bob Sproull, but most equipment was too expensive for consumer use, and its use for games was limited.

A virtual reality game or VR games is a video game played on virtual reality (VR) hardware. Most VR games are based on player immersion, typically through head-mounted display unit or headset with stereoscopic displays and one or more controllers.
The video game industry made early attempts at VR in the 1980s, most notably with Mattel's Power Glove and Nintendo's Virtual Boy. With the introduction of the first consumer-ready VR product, the Oculus Rift, in 2013, VR games soon followed, including existing games adapted for the VR hardware, and new games designed directly for VR. While VR hardware and games grew modestly for the remainder of the 2010s, Half-Life: Alyx, a full VR game developed by Valve, was considered the killer application for VR games.


== History ==


=== Early VR games (1980s-2000s) ===
Research into virtual reality (VR) hardware and software started as early as 1968 by Ivan Sutherland and his student Bob Sproull, but most equipment was too expensive for consumer use, and its use for games was limited.

document: Rashida Harbi Tlaib, an American politician and lawyer, has been serving as the U.S. representative for Michigan's 12th congressional district since 2019. document: A brain-computer interface (BCI), also known as a brain-machine interface (BMI) or smartbrain, establishes a direct communication pathway between the brain's electrical activity and an external device, such as a computer or robotic limb. BCIs have diverse applications, ranging from research and mapping of human cognitive or sensory-motor functions, to assisting and augmenting these functions, and even repairing them. They eliminate the need for physical body movements, as they create a direct link between the brain and machines. BCIs can be implemented in various ways, from non-invasive methods like EEG and MRI, to partially invasive techniques such as ECoG and endovascular methods, and invasive approaches like microelectrode arrays. The study of BCIs originated in the 1970s at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) by Jacques Vidal, and the term "brain-computer interface" first appeared in scientific literature in Vidal's 1973 paper. One compelling aspect of BCIs is their ability to leverage the brain's plasticity, allowing signals from implanted devices to be processed by the brain as if they were natural sensory or motor channels.
noref_document: A brain-computer interface (BCI) is a technology that enables direct communication between the brain and an external device, such as a computer or a prosthetic limb. By interpreting neural signals and translating them into commands, BCIs allow individuals with disabilities to regain mobility, communicate without speech, or control robotic devices using their thoughts alone. This cutting-edge field of research holds great promise for revolutionizing the way we interact with technology, opening up possibilities for enhancing human performance, treating neurological disorders, and even expanding the boundaries of human capabilities.
summary:
A brain–computer interface (BCI), sometimes called a brain–machine interface (BMI) or smartbrain, is a direct communication pathway between the brain's electrical activity and an external device, most commonly a computer or robotic limb. BCIs are often directed at researching, mapping, assisting, augmenting, or repairing human cognitive or sensory-motor functions. They are often conceptualized as a human–machine interface that skips the intermediary component of the physical movement of body parts, although they also raise the possibility of the erasure of the discreteness of brain and machine. Implementations of BCIs range from non-invasive (EEG, MEG, EOG, MRI) and partially invasive (ECoG and endovascular) to invasive (microelectrode array), based on how close electrodes get to brain tissue.Research on BCIs began in the 1970s by Jacques Vidal at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) under a grant from the National Science Foundation, followed by a contract from DARPA. Vidal's 1973 paper marks the first appearance of the expression brain–computer interface in scientific literature.
Due to the cortical plasticity of the brain, signals from implanted prostheses can, after adaptation, be handled by the brain like natural sensor or effector channels.

document: CRISPR gene editing, named after the bacterial defense system it is derived from, is a revolutionary technique in genetic engineering that allows the modification of the genomes of living organisms. By introducing the Cas9 nuclease complexed with a guide RNA into a cell, specific locations within the cell's genome can be targeted for precise editing. This technique has immense significance in biotechnology and medicine, as it provides a highly precise, affordable, and accessible method for genome editing in vivo. Its applications are vast, ranging from the creation of new medicines and agricultural products to the control of pathogens and pests. Furthermore, it holds promising potential in treating inherited genetic diseases and diseases caused by somatic mutations, such as cancer.
noref_document: CRISPR gene editing is a revolutionary technique that has transformed the field of biotechnology. CRISPR, which stands for Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats, is a naturally occurring system found in bacteria that allows scientists to precisely edit genes. This technology has the potential to treat or even cure diseases caused by genetic mutations, such as cancer, HIV, and genetic disorders. By utilizing CRISPR gene editing, scientists can make targeted changes to the DNA of living organisms, opening up a world of possibilities in fields like agriculture, medicine, and bioengineering. The ease and affordability of CRISPR gene editing have made it widely accessible, sparking a global scientific revolution and raising ethical and regulatory concerns.
summary: CRISPR gene editing  (pronounced  "crisper") is a genetic engineering technique in molecular biology by which the genomes of living organisms may be modified. It is based on a simplified version of the bacterial CRISPR-Cas9 antiviral defense system. By delivering the Cas9 nuclease complexed with a synthetic guide RNA (gRNA) into a cell, the cell's genome can be cut at a desired location, allowing existing genes to be removed and/or new ones added in vivo.The technique is considered highly significant in biotechnology and medicine as it enables editing genomes in vivo very precisely, cheaply, and easily. It can be used in the creation of new medicines, agricultural products, and genetically modified organisms, or as a means of controlling pathogens and pests. It also has possibilities in the treatment of inherited genetic diseases as well as diseases arising from somatic mutations such as cancer.

document: Slack, the popular instant messaging program, was initially developed as an internal tool for Stewart Butterfield's company, Tiny Speck, during the creation of the online game Glitch. Since then, it has evolved into much more than just a professional communication platform. Offering various communication channels like voice calls, video calls, text messaging, media sharing, and file transfers, Slack enables users to connect within private chats or as part of larger communities called "workspaces." Taking inspiration from IRC-style features, Slack also facilitates persistent chat rooms organized by topic, private groups, and direct messaging. Moreover, it can seamlessly integrate with other software, enhancing its functionality. Available across multiple platforms including Web, Windows, Linux, MacOS, Android, Windows Phone, and iOS, Slack has become a versatile tool utilized by organizations, professionals, and communities alike.

Founded in 2013, Slack offers a range of features such as chat channels, file sharing, and integration with other business applications. With its user-friendly interface and customizable options, teams can easily organize their conversations into specific topics or projects, enhancing productivity and streamlining workflows. Slack also supports real-time messaging, enabling instant communication and facilitating quick decision-making. Whether teams are working remotely or in the same office, Slack provides a central hub for sharing ideas, collaborating on tasks, and staying connected.
summary:
Slack is an instant messaging program designed by Slack Technologies and owned by Salesforce. Although Slack was developed for professional and organizational communications, it has also been adopted as a community platform. Users can communicate with voice calls, video calls, text messaging, media, and files in private chats or as part of communities called "workspaces." Slack also uses IRC-style features such as persistent chat rooms (channels) organized by topic, private groups, and direct messaging. In addition to these online communication features, Slack can integrate with other software. Slack runs on Web, Windows, Linux, MacOS, Android, Windows Phone and iOS.


== History ==
Slack began as an internal tool for Stewart Butterfield's company, Tiny Speck, during the development of Glitch, an online game.

document: Ubisoft Entertainment SA is a renowned French video game publisher with a global presence. Headquartered in Saint-Mandé, Ubisoft has development studios scattered across the world. The company boasts an impressive lineup of successful video game franchises, including Assassin's Creed, Far Cry, For Honor, Just Dance, Prince of Persia, Rabbids, Rayman, Tom Clancy's, and Watch Dogs. Established in 1986, Ubisoft's origin lies in the Guillemot family's support business for farmers in France and the United Kingdom. The five sons of the family, namely Christian, Claude, Gérard, Michel, and Yves, obtained valuable business experience during their time at university before returning to the family business and contributing to its sales, distribution, accounting, and management.
noref_document: Ubisoft is a renowned French video game company known for developing and publishing a diverse range of critically acclaimed titles. Founded in 1986 by the Guillemot brothers, Ubisoft has become one of the most prominent players in the gaming industry. With its headquarters in Montreuil, France, the company operates through a network of studios located all around the world. Ubisoft is widely recognized for its captivating storytelling, immersive gameplay, and high-quality graphics. The company has created numerous successful franchises, including Assassin's Creed, Far Cry, and Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six. Committed to innovation and pushing the boundaries of gaming, Ubisoft continues to strive for excellence and engage players with thrilling and memorable experiences.
summary:
Ubisoft Entertainment SA (; French: [ybisɔft]; formerly Ubi Soft Entertainment SA) is a French video game publisher headquartered in Saint-Mandé with development studios across the world. Its video game franchises include Assassin's Creed, Far Cry, For Honor, Just Dance, Prince of Persia, Rabbids, Rayman, Tom Clancy's, and Watch Dogs.


== History ==


=== Origins and first decade (1986–1996) ===
By the 1980s, the Guillemot family had established themselves as a support business for farmers in the Brittany province of France and other regions, including into the United Kingdom. The five sons of the family – Christian, Claude, Gérard, Michel, and Yves – helped with the company's sales, distribution, accounting, and management with their parents before university. All five gained business experience while at university, which they brought back to the family business after graduating.

document: Adam Silver, the current commissioner of the National Basketball Association (NBA), has made a significant impact on the league since taking the position in 2014. Prior to becoming the commissioner, Silver had already established a solid foundation within the NBA, holding various roles including chief operating officer and deputy commissioner. Under his leadership, the NBA has experienced considerable growth, both economically and globally. One particular milestone during Silver's tenure was his handling of the Donald Sterling controversy in 2014, where he forced Sterling to sell the Los Angeles Clippers and banned him from all NBA games and events. Silver's decisive action showcased his commitment to maintaining the integrity of the NBA and addressing issues of racism within the league.
noref_document: Adam Silver is an American lawyer and the current commissioner of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He has been praised for his progressive leadership, focusing on both the on-court game and the business side of the league. Under Silver's tenure, the NBA has experienced significant growth and expansion, implementing various rule changes and advancements in technology to enhance the fan experience. Silver is also known for his commitment to social justice and player empowerment, encouraging players to use their platforms to speak out on important societal issues. His forward-thinking approach has helped solidify the NBA's position as a global sports powerhouse.
summary:
Adam Silver (born April 25, 1962) is an American lawyer and sports executive who serves as the fifth and current commissioner of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He joined the NBA in 1992 and has held various positions within the league, becoming chief operating officer and deputy commissioner under his predecessor and mentor David Stern in 2006. When Stern retired in 2014, Silver was named the new commissioner.
During Silver's tenure, the league has continued to grow economically and globally, especially in China. Silver made headlines in 2014 for forcing Donald Sterling to sell the Los Angeles Clippers, then banning Sterling for life from all NBA games and events following racist remarks.

document: Roblox is an immersive online game platform and game creation system that offers a unique experience to its users. Created by David Baszucki and Erik Cassel in 2004, but only released in 2006, Roblox started off as a relatively small platform. However, in recent years, it has experienced exponential growth, which has been further accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic. The platform allows users to not only play games created by others but also gives them the opportunity to program and create their own games using the programming language Lua. With over 164 million monthly active users as of August 2020, Roblox has become a popular online destination, especially among American children under 16. The platform is free to play, but offers in-game purchases through a virtual currency called Robux, adding an extra layer of customization and personalization to the user experience.

With its user-friendly interface and extensive library of assets, Roblox empowers individuals to bring their imaginations to life and share their creations with a global community. Players can explore unique virtual worlds, engage in social activities, and collaborate with others on exciting projects. From role-playing adventures to obstacle courses and virtual hangouts, Roblox offers endless possibilities for entertainment and creativity.
summary: Roblox () is an online game platform and game creation system developed by Roblox Corporation that allows users to program games and play games created by other users. Created by David Baszucki and Erik Cassel in 2004 and released in 2006, the platform hosts user-created games of multiple genres coded in the programming language Lua. For most of Roblox's history, it was relatively small, both as a platform and as a company. Roblox began to grow rapidly in the second half of the 2010s, and this growth has been accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic.Roblox is free to play, with in-game purchases available through a virtual currency called Robux. As of August 2020, Roblox had over 164 million monthly active users, including more than half of all American children under 16.

document: Laverne Cox, an American actress and LGBT advocate, has made significant strides in breaking barriers and paving the way for inclusivity in the entertainment industry. Her breakthrough role as Sophia Burset on the acclaimed Netflix series Orange Is the New Black not only garnered critical acclaim but also made history as she became the first transgender person to be nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award in an acting category. Cox's impact doesn't stop there; she also won a Daytime Emmy Award for executive producing Laverne Cox Presents: The T Word, marking the first time a trans woman received this honor. Demonstrating her talent and activism, Cox became the first transgender person to play a transgender role as a series regular on U.S. broadcast TV in CBS's Doubt. Beyond her acting career, Cox has appeared on reality TV and co-produced and co-hosted TRANSform Me, a captivating VH1 makeover television series. Her remarkable advocacy work has not gone unnoticed, as she was recognized by GLAAD with the Stephen F. Kolzak Award for her unwavering support for the transgender community.
noref_document: Laverne Cox is an American actress, reality television star, and LGBTQ+ advocate known for her groundbreaking role in "Orange Is the New Black." Cox has become a prominent figure in the entertainment industry, using her platform to raise awareness about transgender rights and people of color within the LGBTQ+ community. She has been recognized for her talent and advocacy work with numerous awards, including a Primetime Emmy nomination. Laverne Cox's success has played a significant role in paving the way for greater representation and acceptance of transgender individuals in mainstream media and society.
summary: Laverne Cox (born May 29, 1972) is an American actress and LGBT advocate. She rose to prominence with her role as Sophia Burset on the Netflix series Orange Is the New Black, becoming the first transgender person to be nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award in an acting category, and the first to be nominated for an Emmy Award since composer Angela Morley in 1990. In 2015, she won a Daytime Emmy Award in Outstanding Special Class Special as executive producer for Laverne Cox Presents: The T Word, making her the first trans woman to win the award. In 2017, she became the first transgender person to play a transgender series regular on U.S. broadcast TV as Cameron Wirth on CBS's Doubt.Cox appeared as a contestant on the first season of VH1's reality show I Want to Work for Diddy, and co-produced and co-hosted the VH1 makeover television series TRANSform Me. In April 2014, Cox was honored by GLAAD with its Stephen F. Kolzak Award for her work as an advocate for the transgender community.

document: Rivian Automotive, Inc., is not your typical electric vehicle manufacturer. With a focus on automotive technology and outdoor recreation, Rivian has carved a niche for itself in the industry. The company boasts an impressive lineup which includes an electric sport utility vehicle (SUV) and pickup truck, both built on their innovative "skateboard" platform. What sets Rivian apart is their forward-thinking approach, as the platform can support future vehicles or be adopted by other companies. Furthermore, Rivian has partnered with Amazon to produce an electric delivery van, known as the Rivian EDV. This collaboration highlights Rivian's commitment to innovation and sustainability. As of late 2021, Rivian has begun deliveries of its highly anticipated R1T pickup truck. Looking ahead, the company has ambitious plans to create an exclusive charging network across the United States and Canada by the end of 2023. Based in Irvine, California, Rivian operates its manufacturing plant in Normal, Illinois, and has other facilities in various locations including Palo Alto, California; Carson, California; Plymouth, Michigan; Vancouver, British Columbia; Wittmann, Arizona; and Woking, England.

document: Kylian Mbappé Lottin, the French forward for Paris Saint-Germain and the captain of the France national team, is hailed as one of the finest footballers in the world. Known for his remarkable dribbling skills, incredible speed, and exceptional finishing, Mbappé has made a significant impact in the sport. Born and raised in Paris, specifically in Bondy, Mbappé began his professional football journey with Monaco in 2015, winning the Ligue 1 title. At the age of 18 in 2017, he secured a permanent transfer to Paris Saint-Germain for a whopping fee of €180 million, making him the second-most-expensive player ever and the most expensive teenage player in history. Since then, Mbappé has achieved numerous triumphs, including five Ligue 1 titles, three Coupes de France, and leading his team to the UEFA Champions League final in 2020. As the all-time leading goalscorer for Paris Saint-Germain and ranking third in assists, Mbappé's impact on the game is truly remarkable.

document: Epic Games, Inc. is well-known as a prominent American video game and software developer and publisher. Based in Cary, North Carolina, Epic Games has grown to become a significant player in the gaming industry.

document: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala is a Nigerian-American economist who made history by becoming the first woman and first African to hold the position of Director-General of the World Trade Organization. In addition to her role at the WTO, she is involved in various prestigious organizations, serving on the boards of Danone, Standard Chartered Bank, MINDS: Mandela Institute for Development Studies, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Georgetown Institute for Women, Peace and Security, One Campaign, GAVI: Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization, Rockefeller Foundation, R4D: Results for Development, ARC: African Risk Capacity, and Earthshot Prize. Prior to her appointment at the WTO, she also sat on the Twitter Board of Directors. Okonjo-Iweala is highly respected in the field of economics and has a long and successful career, including a 25-year tenure at The World Bank, where she eventually became the Managing Director for Operations from 2007 to 2011. She continues to be actively involved in economic development and serves as a non-resident distinguished fellow at the Brookings Institution's Africa Growth Initiative. She is also a Commissioner Emeritus and Co-Chair of the Global Commission on the Economy and Climate.
noref_document: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala is a Nigerian economist and international development expert who has made significant contributions to global finance and governance. As the former Finance Minister of Nigeria and a former Managing Director of the World Bank, Okonjo-Iweala has been instrumental in implementing policies and reforms to improve Nigeria's economy and promote transparency in public financial management. Her expertise and leadership have also been recognized on an international level, as she became the first woman and African to be appointed as the Director-General of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2021. Okonjo-Iweala's impressive track record and commitment to creating more inclusive and equitable economic systems continue to inspire and shape the global conversation on development and trade.
summary: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala  ( (listen); born 13 June 1954) is a Nigerian-American economist, who has been serving as the Director-General of the World Trade Organization since March 2021. Notably, she is the first woman and first African to lead the World Trade Organization as Director-General. She sits on boards of: Danone, Standard Chartered Bank, MINDS: Mandela Institute for Development Studies, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Georgetown Institute for Women, Peace and Security, One Campaign, GAVI: Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization, Rockefeller Foundation, R4D: Results for Development, ARC: African Risk Capacity and Earthshot Prize plus others.She also previously sat on the Twitter Board of Directors, and stepped down in February, 2021 in connection with her appointment as Director General of the World Trade Organization.Okonjo-Iweala serves Brookings Institution as a non-resident distinguished fellow with the Africa Growth Initiative in their Global Economy and Development Program. She is a  Commissioner Emeritus and Co-Chair of Global Commission on the Economy and Climate. At The World Bank, she had a 25-year career as a development economist; rising to become Managing Director for Operations from 2007 to 2011.

document: OneWeb Network Access Associates Limited, a communications company headquartered in London, is at the forefront of the mission to provide broadband satellite Internet services. With offices in Virginia, US, and a satellite manufacturing facility in Florida called Airbus OneWeb Satellites, a joint venture with Airbus Defence and Space, the company has made notable strides in the industry. document: BioNTech SE is a German biotechnology company focused on developing and manufacturing active immunotherapies for personalized treatments of various diseases. In addition to cancer immunotherapies and vaccines against infectious diseases, the company also works on protein replacement therapies for rare diseases, engineered cell therapy, novel antibodies, and small molecule immunomodulators for cancer treatment. BioNTech has successfully developed an mRNA-based human therapeutic for individualized cancer immunotherapy, which has undergone clinical trials and established its own manufacturing process. In collaboration with Pfizer, the company developed the groundbreaking RNA vaccine, BNT162b2, for preventing COVID-19 infections. This vaccine was the first-ever authorized mRNA vaccine and demonstrated a high efficacy of 91% in preventing confirmed COVID-19 cases. Temporary authorization for BNT162b2 was granted by the UK government on 2 December 2020.
noref_document: BioNTech is a German biotechnology company that specializes in the development of immunotherapies for cancer and infectious diseases. Founded in 2008, BioNTech has quickly emerged as a leading player in the field of mRNA-based vaccines. Their groundbreaking collaboration with Pfizer resulted in the development and production of the first authorized COVID-19 vaccine, Comirnaty. Through their mRNA technology, BioNTech has demonstrated the potential to revolutionize medical treatments by harnessing the body's own cellular machinery to combat diseases. With a strong focus on innovation and a commitment to improving global health, BioNTech continues to make significant strides in the field of mRNA therapeutics.
summary:
BioNTech SE ( bee-ON-tek; or  bye-ON-tek short for Biopharmaceutical New Technologies) is a German biotechnology company based in Mainz that develops and manufactures active immunotherapies for patient-specific approaches to the treatment of diseases. It develops pharmaceutical candidates based on messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA) for use as individualized cancer immunotherapies, as vaccines against infectious diseases and as protein replacement therapies for rare diseases, and also engineered cell therapy, novel antibodies and small molecule immunomodulators as treatment options for cancer.
The company has developed an mRNA-based human therapeutic for intravenous administration to bring individualized mRNA-based cancer immunotherapy to clinical trials and to establish its own manufacturing process.In 2020, BioNTech, partnering with Pfizer for testing and logistics, developed the RNA vaccine BNT162b2 for preventing COVID-19 infections, which at the time offered a 91% efficacy in preventing confirmed COVID-19 occurring at least 7 days after the second dose of vaccine. On 2 December 2020, temporary HMR authorization was granted by the United Kingdom government for BNT162b2 vaccinations within the United Kingdom. It was the first mRNA vaccine ever authorized.

document: Waymo LLC, a subsidiary of Alphabet Inc., is an autonomous driving technology company based in Mountain View, California. Originally known as the Google Self-Driving Car Project, Waymo emerged from the Google X lab in 2009 under the leadership of co-founder Sergey Brin. The project was spearheaded by Sebastian Thrun, director of the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, and Anthony Levandowski, founder of 510 Systems and Anthony's Robots. In a corporate restructuring in 2016, the project was rebranded as Waymo. With its foundation in research and innovation, Waymo continues to push the boundaries of self-driving technology.

document: Mohamed Salah, also known as Mo Salah, is an Egyptian professional footballer who plays as a forward for Premier League club Liverpool and captains the Egypt national team. Salah is considered one of the best players of his generation and amongst the greatest African players of all time. Known for his clinical finishing, dribbling, and speed, he started his senior career in 2010 with Al Mokawloon before moving on to Basel, where he won two Swiss Super League titles. After a stint at Chelsea, Salah joined Fiorentina and Roma on loan, before being permanently signed by Roma for €15 million. In the 2016-2017 season, he played a key role in Roma's unsuccessful title bid, contributing with both goals and assists. In 2017, Salah transferred to Liverpool for a then-club record fee of £36.9 million.
